About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
LOAN_USE: to purchase additional products to sell

DESCRIPTION:
Lolita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling fruits and vegetables in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her fruits and vegetables retail business.

Lolita has been in this business for 12 years. Lolita earns additional income from raising pigs.

Lolita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.
LOAN_USE: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell.

DESCRIPTION:
Ruzanna, her husband and two children live in Tsovagyugh village of the Gegharkunik region. Her family has one source of income, from farming.

Ruzanna and her husband take care of their farm cattle, cultivate vegetables and organize their sale to sustain their family’s needs and provide good living conditions for their lovely children.

Ruzanna is upset that among so many financial hardships she has health problems that require funds for her to get better.

Ruzanna will be very thankful to receive this loan of 350.000 Armenian drams.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Ruzanna, her husband and two children live in Tsovagyugh village of the Gegharkunik region. Her family has one source of income, from farming.

Ruzanna and her husband take care of their farm cattle, cultivate vegetables and organize their sale to sustain their family’s needs and provide good living conditions for their lovely children.

Ruzanna is upset that among so many financial hardships she has health problems that require funds for her to get better.

Ruzanna will be very thankful to receive this loan of 350.000 Armenian drams.
LOAN_USE: to solve her health problems.

DESCRIPTION: Le groupe Allakabo est uniquement composé de femmes monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes à Kanadjiguila commune de Mandé / cercle de Kati et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce d’habits, du lait et de condiments. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 3ème  cycle de prêt solidaire.\nMadame Fatoumata  (femme arrêtée à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) a une grande réputation dans la vente des habits (bazins, léger et pagnes wax) de plusieurs qualités. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 15 mètres de bazins, 10 mètres de léger et 10 pièces de pagnes wax  en gros à Bamako. La revente se fait en détails  à une clientèle majoritairement composée de femmes. Madame Fatoumata  espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité. Elle a pour objectif d’acheter un lot à usage d’habitation dans cette relation avec Soro Yiriwaso.\n
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED: The Allakabo group is solely made up of monogamous women. On average, they are 38 years old and have four children. They all live in the Kanadjiguila commune of Mandé/Kati circle and know one another through neighborhood ties. The group members run small businesses selling clothing, milk and vegetables for sauces. With the goal of increasing their business funds, the group members decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso and are on their third group loan cycle. Ms. Fatoumata (the woman at the far left of the photo) has a great reputation in the sale of clothing (damask, light cloth, and traditional, colorful wax cloths) of various qualities. She expects to use her loan to buy 15 meters of damask, 10 meters of light cloth, and 10 traditional, colorful wax cloths at wholesale in Bamako. The resale will take place at retail to a clientele largely made up of women. With this loan, Ms. Fatoumata hopes to make an average monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA which will be used to reinvest in her business. Through her relationship with Soro Yiriwaso, her objective is to buy a plot of land to use for housing.
LOAN_USE: to purchase clothing.

DESCRIPTION: Doña Melania vive en la ciudad de Estelí desde hace cuatro años ella empezó en el negocio de pulpería,   porque su mamá le enseñó desde muy pequeña  a trabajar ya que ellas eran de escasos recursos vendían tortillas en la calle y siempre le ha gustado el negocio entonces ella con sus ahorros decidió poner su pequeña pulpería compró diez libras de arroz cinco litros de aceite, café y pan y así fue comprando poco a poco ella tiene como expectativa seguir creciendo está ubicada en un buen punto de venta cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo y su hijo adolecente el cual está estudiando y es la razón que la impulsa a seguir adelante. Solicita este crédito para la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite, maíz, frijoles, gaseosas y golosinas productos básicos para la venta.  Sus planes futuros son mejorar la condición de su vivienda y la venta agregando  productos nuevos  para vender.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED: Melania lives in the city of Estelí, and four years ago she opened a small grocery store.  Her mother taught her to work from a young age, and since they were of limited resources they sold tortillas on the street.  Since she always enjoyed business, she decided to use her savings to open her small grocery store. She started by buying ten pounds of rice, five liters of oil, coffee and bread, and little by little she kept buying goods.  \r\n\r\nShe hopes to continue growing as her store is in a good selling location.  She counts on the support of her husband and teenage son, who is currently in school, and is the reason for her strive to succeed.  She is requesting this loan in order to purchase rice, sugar, oil, corn, beans, soda, snacks and other basic products to sell.  Her future plans are to improve her living conditions and her sales by adding new products for sale.
LOAN_USE: to purchase rice, sugar, oil, corn, beans, soda and snacks, basic products to sell

DESCRIPTION:
Jessie works hard to support six children. She is married and has an oyster fattening business in the Philippines.

Jessie requested a 2,100 PHP loan through NWTF to buy a solar lamp.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to provide her children with bright light when they study at night.

Jessie is aware that by using the solar lamp she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health risks and hazards to her family.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Jessie works hard to support six children. She is married and has an oyster fattening business in the Philippines.

Jessie requested a 2,100 PHP loan through NWTF to buy a solar lamp.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to provide her children with bright light when they study at night.

Jessie is aware that by using the solar lamp she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health risks and hazards to her family.
LOAN_USE: to buy a solar lamp.

DESCRIPTION: Ba is a fifty-eight-year-old married woman with four children, two sons and two daughters. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. She and her husband run a general store and sell beverages and coffee to people in their community. She started this business six years ago.\r\n  \r\nBa would like a loan to buy new products such as a large variety of cakes, green tea, milk and beverages to sell in her store to better meet her customers' needs. She hopes that she will be able to increase her income and set aside some savings through the loan.
LOAN_USE: To buy new products such as a variety of cakes, green tea, milk and beverages to sell in her store.

DESCRIPTION:
Vitelia es una mujer de 25 años de edad, es viuda, vive junto a sus tres hijos de 12, 8 y otro de 4 años, dos de ellos se encuentran estudiando en educación básica. Ella tiene un nivel académico de noveno grado, trabaja en una empresa en limpieza de mariscos para la exportación del mismo desde hace siete años. 


El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar  madera, tejas y cementó para la construcción de su vivienda en la propiedad que su padre le otorgo.  Trasladara todos estos materiales aproximadamente unos cuatro kilómetros hasta el lugar en donde los necesita. .  

Ella tiene proyectado,  que sus hijos tengan un buen nivel académico que les permita desempeñar cualquier actividad laboral y poseer una vivienda que reúna las condicione para su familia.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Vitelia is a 25 year old woman who lives with her three children, ages 12, 8, and 4.  Two of them attend elementary school.  She has a ninth grade education and for seven years has been working for a seafood exporting company.

She is asking for a loan through Fundación Campo so she can buy lumber, tiles, and cement to build her house on a piece of land that her father gave her.  She will move all the materials about four km to where she needs them.

She plans for her children to have a good level of education so they can do whatever they want.  She also wants to have a house for her family.
LOAN_USE: to build a house.

DESCRIPTION:
Grace N. is a 30 year old married mother of 4 (16, 14, 13, 3) who has a retail shop as well as livestock. With the loan, she will purchase more stock for her retail store as well as purchase 2 goats. With the profits she will buy a calf and 3 more piglets.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.
LOAN_USE: To increase her stock

DESCRIPTION: Asporo lives in Kamwenge, Uganda, where he deals in produce buying and selling, especially beans and maize. He has four children, all of whom attend school. He supplements his income with crop growing where he gets more income and supports his family. He has a motive of expanding his business into a big store and educating all his children to higher levels in Ugandan education. However, he is challenged by price fluctuations and inadequate capital to meet both the family and business needs. He is requesting a loan to buy more maize, beans, sorghum and millet to sell.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED: Asporo lives in Kamwenge, Uganda, where he deals in produce buying and selling, especially beans and maize. He has four children, all of whom attend school. He supplements his income with crop growing where he gets more income and supports his family. He has a motive of expanding his business into a big store and educating all his children to higher levels in Ugandan education. However, he is challenged by price fluctuations and inadequate capital to meet both the family and business needs. He is requesting a loan to buy more maize, beans, sorghum and millet to sell.
LOAN_USE: to buy more maize, beans, sorghum and millet to sell.

DESCRIPTION:
Ma Pinky is married and she works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines. Ma Pinky is borrowing PHP 16,000 through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell for her general store business.

Ma Pinky has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Ma Pinky is married and she works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines. Ma Pinky is borrowing PHP 16,000 through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell for her general store business.

Ma Pinky has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.
LOAN_USE: to buy more groceries to sell.

DESCRIPTION:
Beatrice is married and has two children,  one who attends school while the other is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Beatrice operates a food selling business, making dumplings and flat bread for sale. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 35,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Beatrice is married and has two children,  one who attends school while the other is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Beatrice operates a food selling business, making dumplings and flat bread for sale. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 35,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.
LOAN_USE: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar.

DESCRIPTION:
Naboth is a resident of Ntungamo district. He is married with children in school. Naboth grows bananas as his main source of income. He also does livestock farming to supplement his income, though on a small scale.

Naboth is confident that this loan will improve his farming business because he will be able to buy fertilizer for his farm to improve his yields. The proceeds from the sale of bananas will cater to the educational costs of his children. He appreciates the lenders.

Pictured is Naboth with his wife and one of his children.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Naboth is a resident of Ntungamo district. He is married with children in school. Naboth grows bananas as his main source of income. He also does livestock farming to supplement his income, though on a small scale.

Naboth is confident that this loan will improve his farming business because he will be able to buy fertilizer for his farm to improve his yields. The proceeds from the sale of bananas will cater to the educational costs of his children. He appreciates the lenders.

Pictured is Naboth with his wife and one of his children.
LOAN_USE: to buy fertilizer for his farm to improve yields, which he will sell to raise school fees for his children.

DESCRIPTION:
Ruzanna is 48 years old and she lives in Sevan city of the Gegharkunik region. She has a higher pedagogical education and for many years until now she has worked at the school as a teacher.

Ruzanna is married and she has two daughters. Her elder daughter is employed and she works at the college and her younger daughter is a student. Ruzanna’s husband is unemployed.

Ruzanna is asking for this loan of 700,000 Armenian drams as she has some health problems and lacks money to solve those problems. With this loan amount she will be able to get a proper and good medical exam and find out the reason for feeling weak and unhealthy.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Ruzanna is 48 years old and she lives in Sevan city of the Gegharkunik region. She has a higher pedagogical education and for many years until now she has worked at the school as a teacher.

Ruzanna is married and she has two daughters. Her elder daughter is employed and she works at the college and her younger daughter is a student. Ruzanna’s husband is unemployed.

Ruzanna is asking for this loan of 700,000 Armenian drams as she has some health problems and lacks money to solve those problems. With this loan amount she will be able to get a proper and good medical exam and find out the reason for feeling weak and unhealthy.
LOAN_USE: to get a proper and good medical exam to find out the reason for feeling weak and unhealthy.

DESCRIPTION: Хайринисо очень благодарна за поддержку и заботу. Она целенаправленно воспользовалась кредитом и получила прибыль. Хайринисо решила за счет прибыли открыть еще одну деятельность по продажи риса. Она хочет открыть магазин по продаже риса по оптовой цене. К сожалению у нее не хватает денег для открытия этого нового бизнеса и она просит поддержки у Вас. Хайринисо будет дополнительный источник дохода. Она заранее благодарна Вам.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED: Khayriniso is very grateful for your support and assistance.  She purposefully used her last loan and turned a profit.  She has decided to open another business selling rice with this income.  Khayriniso wants to open up a wholesale rice outlet.  Unfortunately, she doesn't have enough money to start this new business and she is asking for your support.   This will be an additional source of income for Khayriniso.  She sends her thanks in advance.
LOAN_USE: to start a new business selling rice at wholesale prices as an additional source of income.

DESCRIPTION: Гулгоокы успешно погасила свой кредит, она благодарна Фонду Кива и всем, кто помог ей в финансировании. В хозяйстве Гулгоокы на сегодняшний день имеется 5 коров и 14 овец, а также земельная доля мерою 1,82 ГА на которой она выращивает картофель и клевер. В целях дальнейшего развития своего дела, Гулгоокы вновь обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 30,000 сом (KGS) на покупку удобрений и 4 овец для увеличения объема сельскохозяйственной продукции и поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита она планирует использовать на дальнейшее увеличение поголовья скота и на ремонт дома.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED: Gulgooky successfully repaid her loan, she is grateful to Kiva and all those who helped her with financing. There are 5 cows and 14 sheep on Gulgooky's farm today, as well as a land share of 1.82 hectares on which she grows potatoes and clover. In order to further develop her business, Gulgooky again applied to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 30,000 KGS to purchase fertilizers and 4 sheep to increase the volume of agricultural products and livestock. She plans to use the loan to further increase the number of livestock and to repair her house.
LOAN_USE: to buy fertilizers and 4 sheep in order to increase agricultural production and the number of livestock.

DESCRIPTION:
Anita A. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 50 years old. Anita is married and has three grown children. To make a living, Anita owns and operates a business providing pedicure and manicure services to local community members. She also sells Natasha and Avon products like polo shirts. Anita has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Anita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Anita is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed for the maintenance of her pedicure and manicure services. This will be the first loan taken by Anita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
LOAN_USE: To purchase supplies for her pedicure and manicure service

DESCRIPTION:
Erlinda is thanking Kiva and its lenders for their continuous support of her livelihood. The loans granted to her have really sustained her burger house. Her earnings helped cover her family's daily sustenance.

To expand her burger house, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan to buy several dozen buns, hamburgers and hot dogs, as well as oil and fuel needed to make more sandwiches and serve more customers. She is positive that her earnings will increase as she increases her business. This will allow her to support her loved ones.

Erlinda aims to open branches in the nearby towns. She hopes to buy a vehicle and to buy a house and a car someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups, each composed of 15 to 30 community partners, that gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Erlinda is thanking Kiva and its lenders for their continuous support of her livelihood. The loans granted to her have really sustained her burger house. Her earnings helped cover her family's daily sustenance.

To expand her burger house, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan to buy several dozen buns, hamburgers and hot dogs, as well as oil and fuel needed to make more sandwiches and serve more customers. She is positive that her earnings will increase as she increases her business. This will allow her to support her loved ones.

Erlinda aims to open branches in the nearby towns. She hopes to buy a vehicle and to buy a house and a car someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups, each composed of 15 to 30 community partners, that gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.
LOAN_USE: to pay for buns, burgers and hot dogs to sell at her burger stand, as well as oil and fuel to prepare them.

DESCRIPTION: Carlos de 23  años de edad, es un emprendedor joven radicado en el municipio de Villeta, Colombia, desde hace más de 3 años se dedica a las labores de cría de pollos de engorde. En la actualidad se encuentra soltero y no tiene hijos pero tiene sus familiares por los cuales vela a fin de garantizarles mejores condiciones de vida y una buena educación. Diariamente comienza su faena realizando actividades de su negocio a fin de tener su empresa en óptimas condiciones para prestar un excelente servicio. Sueña con poder construir una casa para ofrecerle a su familia una vivienda digna. Debido a los altos costos de insumos y los cambios climáticos que perjudican su labor, Carlos se encuentra solicitando un crédito que invertirá en la compra de arreglo de corral, comprar malla, tejas y compra de concentrados, para generar mayores ingresos para el sostenimiento de su hogar\n
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Carlos, who is 23 years old, is a young entrepreneur who has lived in the municipality of Villeta, Colombia, for more than three years. His work is raising broiler chickens. He is now single and has no children, but he has his relatives whom he looks out for with the goal of guaranteeing them better living conditions and a good education.

Every day he begins his work, doing tasks for his business with the goal of having his enterprise in optimal conditions in order to provide excellent service. He dreams of being able to build a house in order to offer his family a dignified home.

Because of the high costs of supplies and the climatic changes that are harmful to his work, Carlos is applying for a loan that he will invest in repairs for the pen and buying mesh, tiles, and feed concentrate in order to generate greater income for the support of his household.
LOAN_USE: to repair the pen and buy mesh, tiles, and feed concentrate.

DESCRIPTION:
Samer, who appears in the photo, is a 32-year-old from a village near Jenin in the West Bank. He is a single young man who lives with his parents and tries so hard to provide his family with all the things they need.

Samer works in farming and plants different types of seeds every season. It is his only source of income. He went to Palestine for Credit and Development (FATEN) to take a US Dollar loan to buy seeds, agricultural fertilizers and pesticides for his farm. This will improve his work and enhance his income. He hopes you will help to fund his loan.

DESCRIPTION:
Sylvia is married and has four children. She is a rural smallholder farmer from the Endebess in the Kitale area of Kenya. The family's main source of income is milk from their dairy farm, but they are also involved in other agricultural activities, such as growing bananas, vegetables, fruits, and grains. The biggest problem that farmers from Endebess face is the huge deficit in access to agricultural supplies, meaning that farmers’ yields and incomes are far below what they could be. 

Juhudi Kilimo partnered with Kiva to provide financial services to smallholder farmers around Kenya. Through these financial services, farmers from Endebess like Sylvia can now buy productive assets and important agricultural supplies for use on their farms. 

Sylvia is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy farm supplies, such as seeds, fertilizer, herbicides, and pesticides. The loan will enable her to improve her production through the use of high-quality farm supplies. This intervention will help her fill the increasing demand for food in the market and, in the process, generate more income. She will not only be able to repay the loan, but will also improve her family's overall quality of life. In particular, Sylvia hopes to improve the conditions of her house.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:

The loan will enable her to improve her production through the use of high-quality farm supplies. DESCRIPTION:
S. Wasay is the group leader of S. Wasay group. There are four members in this group, all of whom hope to expand their businesses:

S. Wasay wants to take out a loan for his general store business in order to purchase more materials for the store, thus significantly expanding its offerings. S. S. would like to obtain a loan for his taxi business and he wants to take on a new mechanic for his taxi. Gul Laden wishes to use his loan for his general store, to which he hopes to attract more clients. Talab Jan would like a loan to use for his car part shop.

The group wants to take out a loan of 56,000 Afghani over a term of 10 months. They are happy to have the opportunity to access the kind of lending process that can support entrepreneurs.
LOAN_USE: For expanding the entrepreneurs' individual businesses.
BORROWER_NAMES: Gul Laden, Sad Sharef, Talab Jan, Sad Wasay

DESCRIPTION:
Evelyn is a married woman with seven children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Evelyn is 52 years old and has two of her children still in school.

Evelyn has a buy-and-sell charcoal business in the Philippines. Evelyn requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

Evelyn has been in this business for six years. In the future, Evelyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:

Evelyn has a buy-and-sell charcoal business in the Philippines. Evelyn requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

Evelyn has been in this business for six years. In the future, Evelyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.
LOAN_USE: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

DESCRIPTION: Allan has worked as a driver for the past 10 years. He is married and lives in Ozamiz City. His business involves motors for hire and public transport. He does this work to support his needs and his family's needs as well. Allan has asked for a loan to pay for the overhaul and maintenance of his motor unit. He wishes to own another unit to increase his income and to save for future emergencies.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED: Allan has worked as a driver for the past 10 years. He is married and lives in Ozamiz City. His business involves motors for hire and public transport. He does this work to support his needs and his family's needs as well. Allan has asked for a loan to pay for the overhaul and maintenance of his motor unit. He wishes to own another unit to increase his income and to save for future emergencies.
LOAN_USE: to pay for the overhaul and maintenance of his motor unit

DESCRIPTION: Nenita is married with 2 children. Nenita is 42 years old and lives in Oroquieta City.\nNenita sells dried fish to earn a living and has had this business for 2 years. Each month, she earns PHP 3000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for 7000 to purchase more different dried fish for her retail business .\nNenita has been a member of PMPC for 1 year.
LOAN_USE: to purchase more dried fish for her retail business

DESCRIPTION:
May has successfully completed her fifth loan cycle and she is requesting a new loan to start up an accommodation business.

The new loan that she is requesting is to buy building materials, such as Masonite, plywood, steel rods, bags of cement, and timbers, to help her complete her new house for accommodation rental.

From her previous loan, she was able to make income, do some home improvements, and pay for some building materials to start off the foundations on her new business.

Her family also benefited from her previous loan, due to the fact that they are now living in an improved home.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
May has successfully completed her fifth loan cycle and she is requesting a new loan to start up an accommodation business.

The new loan that she is requesting is to buy building materials, such as Masonite, plywood, steel rods, bags of cement, and timbers, to help her complete her new house for accommodation rental.

From her previous loan, she was able to make income, do some home improvements, and pay for some building materials to start off the foundations on her new business.

Her family also benefited from her previous loan, due to the fact that they are now living in an improved home.
LOAN_USE: May to buy 20 pieces of masonite, 30 pieces of plywood, steel rods, bags of cement, and timbers for her accommodation business.

DESCRIPTION:
Mrs. Pham Thi L., 50 years old, joined TYM Fund (Kiva's partner) since 2007. She lives with her husband and two children in Lam town, Nam Dinh province. Her province is famous for casting copper. Before L., there have been a lot of women borrowing money to buy and sell copper. However, L. is still afraid of not being able to pay the weekly repayment. Until recently (2007), she decided to borrow 200USD. She uses that loan to buy and then cast copper. Her income is 8 to 10 USD per day. Her business is doing quite well, and this time Mrs. L. would like to borrow 575 USD to buy more materials, to increase her income and bring jobs for her two children.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Phạm Thị L., 50 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2007. Chị sống cùng chồng và 2 con tại thị trấn Lâm, Nam Định. Ở một làng nghề truyền thống đúc đồng, trước chị L. đã có rất nhiều chị em vay vốn về kinh doanh mặt hàng này. Nhưng chị vẫn ngại về cách hoàn trả hàng tuần. Đến năm ngoái chị mới quyết định xin vay 200USD. Trong năm đầu chị đầu tư mua đồng về đúc mỗi ngày cho thu nhập từ 8-10USD. Thấy công việc tiến triển thuận lợi, sang năm thứ 2 này chị Lam mạnh dạn vay thêm 575USD về để mua được nhiều nguyên liệu hơn, tăng thu nhập và tạo công ăn việc làm cho 2 con.
LOAN_USE: Buy copper to cast

DESCRIPTION: El Sr. Mario y su esposa la Sra. Graciela llevan muchos años de casados, ellos viven en zona Radial de la cuidad de Santa Cruz, cuentan con casa propia en la cual  vive con 1 de sus hijos que aun es soltero y estudia y los otros cuatros ya tienen su familia a parte, EL Sr. Mario llego a nuestra oficina por referencia de un compañero de trabajo, Don Mario tiene un vehículo propio del cual tiene un chofer que lo trabaja haciendo servicios transporte urbano el cual le da renta diaria, Doña Graciela tiene una venta de pollo a la Broaster en su mismo domicilio y de esa manera le ayuda a su esposo con los gastos del hogar, el crédito será destinado para el mantenimiento de su vehículo (Chapería en general), "estamos muy agradecidos con su institucion ya que depositaron su confianza en nosotros" dijeron.\t
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Mario and his wife, Graciela, have been married for many years.  They live in the Santa Cruz’s Radial Zone.  They have their own house, and they live with one of their sons.  He is still single and goes to school.  The other four already have their own separate families.

Mario came to our office because he was referred by a work colleague.  Mario has his own vehicle.  He has a driver who works providing urban transportation services.  This gives him his daily income.

Graciela sells broasted chicken in her own home.  That way she helps her husband with the household expenses.

The loan is for maintenance on his vehicle (general sheet metal work).

“We are very grateful to the institution that has placed their trust in us,” they said.
LOAN_USE: to pay for maintenance on his vehicle (general sheet metal work).

DESCRIPTION:
Mrs. Huệ is 36 years old and she is married with 2 children. She has worked in agriculture farming\xa0food for 8 years. Huệ lives in Quang Xuong district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province. Her income is lower than the national average income, moreover, the market need is low in this region.

The main hardship that she faces is lack of money to keep sending her children to school. She is requesting a loan to purchase school supplies and pay the tuition fees for her children.

This is Huệ first loan with Thanh Hoa microfinance institution.

Huệ hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her children to do well in school, and for her business to do well.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:

This is Huệ first loan with Thanh Hoa microfinance institution.

Huệ hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her children to do well in school, and for her business to do well.
LOAN_USE: to purchase school supplies, and pay the tuition fees for her children.

DESCRIPTION:
Lutchie is 24 years old, is single and has two children. Lutchie is in the agricultural business, farming rice in the Philippines. She has requested a 8,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

Lutchie has been in this business for 10 years now and has borrowed from NWTF twice in the past to sustain it. In the future, Lutchie would like to save money to provide for her family and give them a secure future.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:

LOAN_USE: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

DESCRIPTION:
Chhalema is a 39-year-old married woman residing in Alipurduar District, West Bengal.

She is engaged in the dairy business. She rears cows and sells milk and dairy products like ghee, posset, butter, etc. in the local market.

She has a household of 5 members and a monthly income of INR 10,000.

She wants to purchase one more cow to increase milk production and expand her dairy business. She has applied for a loan of INR 40,000 from BJS, one of Milaap's field partners.

She and her family will be thankful to their lenders.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Chhalema is a 39-year-old married woman residing in Alipurduar District, West Bengal.

She is engaged in the dairy business. She rears cows and sells milk and dairy products like ghee, posset, butter, etc. in the local market.

She has a household of 5 members and a monthly income of INR 10,000.

She wants to purchase one more cow to increase milk production and expand her dairy business. She has applied for a loan of INR 40,000 from BJS, one of Milaap's field partners.

She and her family will be thankful to their lenders.
LOAN_USE: to purchase a cow in order to expand her dairy business

DESCRIPTION:
Elizabeth is 42 years old. She is married and blessed with four children. Her business is farming, which she has operated for six years.

This is her second loan. She will use it to buy fertilizers and seeds to improve production. She will use profits from the expanded business to educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to give her children a better future.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Elizabeth is 42 years old. She is married and blessed with four children. Her business is farming, which she has operated for six years.

This is her second loan. She will use it to buy fertilizers and seeds to improve production. She will use profits from the expanded business to educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to give her children a better future.
LOAN_USE: to buy fertilizer and seeds to improve farm production.

DESCRIPTION:
Mona is a 30-year-old married Palestinian refugee, and a mother of two. She’s acquiring this loan from Kiva’s field partner Al Majmoua to pay her childrens' kindergarten school tuition fees. (They're featured with her in the picture).

The loan is a part of Al Majmoua Back to School program designed to finance school expenses such as books, stationery, transportation and fees for students with low family incomes. Funds can be used for partial or complete payment of school expenses. By contributing this loan your enabling access to education for students with limited options.

By contributing this loan, you would be supporting Mona in her attempt to provide her children with proper education.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Mona is a 30-year-old married Palestinian refugee, and a mother of two. She’s acquiring this loan from Kiva’s field partner Al Majmoua to pay her childrens' kindergarten school tuition fees. (They're featured with her in the picture).

The loan is a part of Al Majmoua Back to School program designed to finance school expenses such as books, stationery, transportation and fees for students with low family incomes. Funds can be used for partial or complete payment of school expenses. By contributing this loan your enabling access to education for students with limited options.

By contributing this loan, you would be supporting Mona in her attempt to provide her children with proper education.
LOAN_USE: to pay her childrens' kindergarten school tuition fees.

DESCRIPTION:
Hello, Kiva Community! Meet Jentrix, a hardworking, dairy and crop-farming mother in the heart of Bungoma .She has a small personal business. She is a devoted mum who loves cooking for her family and providing for their basic needs.

However, she has not been enjoying her cooking duties, due to her old, problematic stove (jiko). Her jiko emits a lot of smoke and now takes more than a tin of charcoal, which has become quite costly, as has paraffin.

Jentrix is requesting a loan to buy an eco-friendly jiko to enjoy cooking for her family and save on costs of charcoal and paraffin. Because it's eco-friendly, the jiko will also keep her from contracting any respiratory diseases that may be caused by the increased fumes emitted by her current stove. Kindly lend to her!
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Hello, Kiva Community! Meet Jentrix, a hardworking, dairy and crop-farming mother in the heart of Bungoma .She has a small personal business. She is a devoted mum who loves cooking for her family and providing for their basic needs.

However, she has not been enjoying her cooking duties, due to her old, problematic stove (jiko). Her jiko emits a lot of smoke and now takes more than a tin of charcoal, which has become quite costly, as has paraffin.

Jentrix is requesting a loan to buy an eco-friendly jiko to enjoy cooking for her family and save on costs of charcoal and paraffin. Because it's eco-friendly, the jiko will also keep her from contracting any respiratory diseases that may be caused by the increased fumes emitted by her current stove. Kindly lend to her!
LOAN_USE: to buy an eco-friendly stove.

DESCRIPTION:
Hakob lives in Ashotsq village in Shirak region with his wife and their two kids. 
He has been doing auto repair service for already 10 years. In the rented garage, Hakob works hard to satisfy customers' needs and gather income for his family.
To prepare his business for the cold and severe winter in Shirak region, Hakob has requested this loan. 
He needs to purchase  tools and materials for auto repair service and also renovation of the garage so his business will be developed. Hakob hopes to obtain a constant source of income which will permit him to provide his family with a better living conditions.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Hakob lives in Ashotsq village in Shirak region with his wife and their two kids.

He needs to purchase  tools and materials for auto repair service and also renovation of the garage so his business will be developed. Hakob hopes to obtain a constant source of income which will permit him to provide his family with a better living conditions.
LOAN_USE: to pay for tools and materials for his auto repair service and also renovation of the garage so his business will be developed .

DESCRIPTION: This Kiva borrower is a 20-year-old married woman living with her husband and one young child. She is from Lebanon. She works producing handicrafts and she's a very artistically talented young woman. She works upon requests of her customers. She works hard in cooperation with her husband who works in the Lebanese general security to provide her family with extra financial support. \r\n\r\nToday, she is requesting to borrow $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to buy textiles and tailoring supplies needed in order to increase her business productivity. In the future, she is planning to open her own tailoring shop.
LOAN_USE: to buy textiles and tailoring supplies.

DESCRIPTION:
Glenda works hard to support her two children. She is single and runs a general store business in the Philippines.

Glenda requested a PHP 7000 loan through NWTF to invest in a a sanitary toilet.

Glenda is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is not only saving money, she is helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Glenda works hard to support her two children. She is single and runs a general store business in the Philippines.

Glenda requested a PHP 7000 loan through NWTF to invest in a a sanitary toilet.

Glenda is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is not only saving money, she is helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.
LOAN_USE: to build a sanitary toilet for her family

DESCRIPTION: Aged 39, Nay lives in a village in the Ponhea Krek district of Cambodia. She is married with four children: three daughters and one son, who are still dependent on her and still in school.  During their spare time, the children help and work at the family's business.  She and her husband earn a living through farming rice and producing palm juice.  They have been in this business for nine years. \r\n\r\nShe is leading a group of two members and this is her second loan with VisionFund.  Her group member has just joined with VisionFund this loan cycle.  She now earns US$8 per day from her current business.  With her request for this small loan with VisionFund, she will use the entire loan to buy fertilizer and plant cassava as additional business items to better earn income.  She hopes to increase her business and make a better living.
LOAN_USE: To buy fertilizer and plant cassava.
TOWN_NAME: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

DESCRIPTION:
Shaista is 39-year-old woman who has been running a low cost school in a small community. There are 214 students enrolled in the school and 62% of them are female students.

The aim of the school is to ensure that all students have basic competencies needed later for practical life. The students are encouraged to set personal learning targets and goals. The main focus is to convert the students into productive resources who bring benefit to the overall society.

Shaista knows that physical environment of the school should also facilitate the students. However, due to lack of funds, broken furniture is used by students. She has requested PKR 200,000 to repair the furniture and building of the school.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Shaista is 39-year-old woman who has been running a low cost school in a small community. There are 214 students enrolled in the school and 62% of them are female students.

The aim of the school is to ensure that all students have basic competencies needed later for practical life. The students are encouraged to set personal learning targets and goals. The main focus is to convert the students into productive resources who bring benefit to the overall society.

Shaista knows that physical environment of the school should also facilitate the students. However, due to lack of funds, broken furniture is used by students. She has requested PKR 200,000 to repair the furniture and building of the school.
LOAN_USE: to repair the furniture and building of the school.

DESCRIPTION: Mariée et mère de deux enfants, Adjilounou est une femme âgée de 27 ans résidant à Tokoin. Adjilounou est une commerçante de bijoux et de pagnes, qui achète et revend ses marchandises au marché. Adjilounou désire ce crédit pour commander des douzaines de colliers et bracelet, ainsi que des pièces de pagnes. Adjilounou souhaite réaliser des bénéfices pour soutenir son mari dans les charges de la famille et permettre une bonne éducation à ses enfants
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Adjilounou is 27 years old, married, and the mother of two children. She lives in Tokoin. Adjilounou sells jewelry and pagnes (traditional wraparounds). She buys and sells her goods at the market.

Adjilounou wants this loan so she can order pagnes and dozens of necklaces and bracelets. She wants to earn money to support her husband with the family's expenses and give her children a quality education.
LOAN_USE: buy 5 dozen necklaces, 3 dozen bracelets, and 12 pagnes (traditional wraparounds).

DESCRIPTION:
Imelda is 53 years old and married with two children. With two of her children in school, she works very hard to provide for them.

Imelda runs a food stall in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Imelda has been in this business for 10 years.

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Imelda is 53 years old and married with two children. With two of her children in school, she works very hard to provide for them.

Imelda runs a food stall in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Imelda has been in this business for 10 years.

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.
LOAN_USE: to buy ingredients for her food production business

She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to invest in a sanitary toilet.

She is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is not only saving money but she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

DESCRIPTION:
Hawa is 26 years old and lives in West Point, a very crowded community that is well-known in Montserrado County. She is married with three children with ages ranging from 3 months to 10 years old. She is living together with her husband and kids at home. Two of the children are in school while the other is still a baby. Her husband is a potential businessman who assists her with some business etiquette.

Hawa sells soap around and in the local market every day. The business has been on-going for the past two years. She obtained this business by selling cold water. Since then, she has not encountered any problem from her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase more soap in order to expand her sales. She even has thought of building her dream house.
LOAN_USE: to purchase more soap in order to expand her sales.

DESCRIPTION:
Joyce is a married woman and has two school going children. She owns a house that neither has electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past five years, she has operated a dairy farming business, selling as retail and at the market to her local residents and restaurant operators. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation.

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase medicine for livestock and cow feeds. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Joyce is a married woman and has two school going children. She owns a house that neither has electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past five years, she has operated a dairy farming business, selling as retail and at the market to her local residents and restaurant operators. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation.

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase medicine for livestock and cow feeds. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business
LOAN_USE: to purchase medicine for livestock and cow feeds

DESCRIPTION:
As a married mother of three children, Ma. Isabelita works hard to support her family.

She has a jeepney transportation business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from frozen foods. Ma. Isabelita is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to  buy spare parts for her jeepney transportation.

Ma. Isabelita has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.
LOAN_USE: to buy spare parts for her jeepney

DESCRIPTION:
Concepcion is 47 years old. Her husband is a fisherman. They have seven children, four of whom are already married. Three children are attending school.

Concepcion's husband catches fish in the early dawn and usually goes home at 10:00 o'clock in the morning. Then a buyer purchases the catch and sells it at the local market .

Concepcion has availed herself of loans many times and successfully repaid them. Now she is taking another loan to purchase fishing materials, such as a fishing net and hooks.

Concepcion wants to renovate her house through her savings.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:

Concepcion has availed herself of loans many times and successfully repaid them. Now she is taking another loan to purchase fishing materials, such as a fishing net and hooks.

Concepcion wants to renovate her house through her savings.
LOAN_USE: to purchase fishing materials

DESCRIPTION:
Arlene is 42 years old and has three children. Arlene is married and has three children are currently in school.

Arlene is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Arlene requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds, vaccine, vitamins and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Arlene has been in this business for 2 years now and has borrowed 3 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

She would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

Arlene has been in this business for 2 years now and has borrowed 3 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

DESCRIPTION:
As a married mother of three children, Diosan works hard to support her family.

She has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines and also earns income from a general store and buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing. Diosan is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell for her vegetable vending business.

Diosan has been sustaining her business activities through her past 27 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

Diosan has been sustaining her business activities through her past 27 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.
