However, due to financial constraints, he is compelled to receive a new loan. Therefore, Rafia requested a Kiva loan for her husband so that he can be able to buy new spare parts for assembling sewing machines.

Rafia gives thanks to Kiva, Kiva’s lenders and its field partner, BRAC Pakistan.
LOAN_USE: to buy sewing machine spare parts for her husband's workshop so he can assemble sewing machines for resale.

DESCRIPTION:
Josefina runs a food stall. She used a prior loan to buy needed ingredients for her food vending business. Josefina would like to thank everyone who helped and contributed to funding her loan. She used some of her profits as a revolving fund for her business and to provide future savings.

Josefina is requesting a loan to buy different ingredients for her food vending business such as rice, pork, chicken, beef, fish, condiments, and spices. Aside from expanding her business, she hopes to improve her living conditions.

Josefina is a member of the Center for Community Transformation and meets weekly with her fellowship partners to share her life’s testimony and business experience. She draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and listening to the Word of God. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 20 members who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social relationships among partners, and pay microfinance loans.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Josefina runs a food stall. She used a prior loan to buy needed ingredients for her food vending business. Josefina would like to thank everyone who helped and contributed to funding her loan. She used some of her profits as a revolving fund for her business and to provide future savings.

Josefina is requesting a loan to buy different ingredients for her food vending business such as rice, pork, chicken, beef, fish, condiments, and spices. Aside from expanding her business, she hopes to improve her living conditions.

Josefina is a member of the Center for Community Transformation and meets weekly with her fellowship partners to share her life’s testimony and business experience. She draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and listening to the Word of God. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 20 members who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social relationships among partners, and pay microfinance loans.
LOAN_USE: to buy ingredients such as rice, pork, chicken, beef, fish, condiments, and spices.

DESCRIPTION:
Las 13 integrantes de este grupo llamado potrero de zona b están ayudándose las unas a las otras para poder salir adelante. Están luchando por poder dar a sus hijos lo que ellas no pudieron tener. Una persona digna de destacar es Alcidia, quien además de ser miembro es la presidenta de este grupo. 
Ella se dedica a la cría, faena y venta de cerdos, es un trabajo muy difícil el que ella hace, pero está dispuesta a hacerlo para poder dar a su familia las mejores comodidades. Quiere que conforme pase el tiempo le vaya mejor en su trabajo, es por eso que sigue luchando.
Solicita de este crédito para comprar cerditos pequeños para la cría y faena de los mismos, y así seguir luchando como lo viene haciendo.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
The 13 members of the communal bank "Potrero de Zona B" are helping each other get ahead.  They are struggling to give their children everything they never had.  One of the outstanding members, Alcidia, is also the president of the group.  She raises and sells pigs, which is a difficult job to do.  But she is willing to do whatever it takes to give her family a comfortable lifestyle.  Over time she wants to improve her work and is striving toward that goal. 

She is requesting a loan to buy piglets to raise and sell, allowing her to continue in her line of work.
LOAN_USE: To buy pigs to raise.
BORROWER_NAMES: Zunilda, Cintia, Maxima, Rufina, Alcidia, Wilfrida, Laura, Marta, Aida, Alba, Florentin, Maria, Cinthia
BORROWER_GENDERS: female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female, female
BORROWER_PICTURED: true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true, true

DESCRIPTION: Juana de 57 años de edad vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, ella se dedica desde hace 5 años a la venta de tortillas, gracias a su trabajo es como ha podido salir adelante con los gastos de su hogar, ella quiere mejorar su vivienda cambiando el techo y constuyendo nuevas paredes, pero con lo que obtiene de su trabajo no le alcanza para realizar dicho proyecto, por esa razon solicita a INTEGRAL un credito para la compra de los materiales de contruccion necesarios y asi poder tener una vivienda mas segura.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED: Juana, who is 57, lives in her own home with her family. She has been selling tortillas for five years. Thanks to this job she has been able to get ahead on household expenses. She would like to improve her home by changing the ceiling and constructing new walls, but with what she earns at work she can't afford that project. For this reason, she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner INTEGRAL to buy materials necessary for construction and thereby be able to have more secure housing.
LOAN_USE: buy necessary materials for construction.

DESCRIPTION:
Silika is 31 years old, married, with one child. She owns and operates a small store, selling items such as snacks, sugar, salt, rice, canned food ,and freezers. She has been doing this for three years.

Silika needs a loan to refill her stock and improve her house. She hopes to use her profits to extend her shop. 

She became a member of SPBD in 2010 to gain access to capital for her business.
LOAN_USE: to restock her inventory of sugar, salt, rice, snacks, and canned food, etc

DESCRIPTION:
Yuccabeth is not scared by the various encounters that she passes through in her life. Through farming, she feels secure to face her future. She is a married woman from a rural village in Kitale. Her work is to raise dairy animals and to grow different crops varieties. She never had a formal education and is content with the farming lifestyle.

In Kenya, agriculture is one of the most competitive industries and especially due to the high costs of operations necessary to improve farming. Such costs include the cost of land acquisition and inputs which have always skyrocketed. To meet the high costs of inputs, farmers have been forced to borrow from financial institutions, which sometimes imposes very complicated procedures in loans distribution. Some farmers, and especially women, end up in hopelessness, despondency and lack of morale to invest in agriculture.

Yuccabeth is a knowledgeable farmer, who knows what she needs to improve her production.. With your support her produce will be doubled and this will consequently reflect in her pocket. Her dreams of becoming an independent will be achieved. Support Yuccabeth today and be part of her big dream.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Yuccabeth is not scared by the various encounters that she passes through in her life. Through farming, she feels secure to face her future. She is a married woman from a rural village in Kitale. Her work is to raise dairy animals and to grow different crops varieties. She never had a formal education and is content with the farming lifestyle.

In Kenya, agriculture is one of the most competitive industries and especially due to the high costs of operations necessary to improve farming. Such costs include the cost of land acquisition and inputs which have always skyrocketed. To meet the high costs of inputs, farmers have been forced to borrow from financial institutions, which sometimes imposes very complicated procedures in loans distribution. Some farmers, and especially women, end up in hopelessness, despondency and lack of morale to invest in agriculture.

Yuccabeth is a knowledgeable farmer, who knows what she needs to improve her production.. With your support her produce will be doubled and this will consequently reflect in her pocket. Her dreams of becoming an independent will be achieved. Support Yuccabeth today and be part of her big dream.
LOAN_USE: to buy farm inputs such as seeds and high-nutrient fertilizers to improve production, increase profits, and pay her children's school fees.

DESCRIPTION:
Wehdeh is a wonderful, hardworking woman who tries her utmost to provide her family with a decent life. She is a 56-year-old mother of four daughters, living with her family in Jericho, West Bank.

She works in a kindergarten in order to help her husband with the family expenses. Her husband works as a taxi driver, where he earns a low income. Wehdeh decided to open a kindergarten after her work in her house in order to enhance the family's living standards.

She turned to Palestine for Credit and Development (FATEN) to request a loan to buy chairs, tables, toys, and other needed supplies for her kindergarten.

She hopes you will help by funding her loan.

DESCRIPTION:
Paulette is 41 years old and married with one child.

She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. Paulette is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Paulette has been pig fattening for three years and also earns additional income from her general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:

Paulette has been pig fattening for three years and also earns additional income from her general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.
LOAN_USE: to buy feed and other supplies to raise her pigs.

DESCRIPTION:
Delefina is a 62-year-old maize farmer in Mwanganthia, Kenya. She historically struggles to access credit for high quality seeds and fertilizer, which compromises the quality of her harvest. Delefina is excited to have access to high quality inputs, advice and insurance from an Apollo Agriculture loan, to increase her yields.

With this bundled package, Delefina expects higher profits this season, which she hopes to invest back into her farm in subsequent seasons.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Delefina is a 62-year-old maize farmer in Mwanganthia, Kenya. She historically struggles to access credit for high quality seeds and fertilizer, which compromises the quality of her harvest. Delefina is excited to have access to high quality inputs, advice and insurance from an Apollo Agriculture loan, to increase her yields.

With this bundled package, Delefina expects higher profits this season, which she hopes to invest back into her farm in subsequent seasons.
LOAN_USE: to access premium seeds and high quality fertilizer for 1 acre of maize, in addition to advice and insurance, optimizing for increased productivity and profits

DESCRIPTION:
Merlita works hard to support her six children. She is married and has a general store in the Philippines.

Merlita requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to build a sanitary toilet for her family.

Merlita is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is reducing health and hazard risks to her family and neighbors as well as promoting environmental protection.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Merlita works hard to support her six children. She is married and has a general store in the Philippines.

Merlita requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to build a sanitary toilet for her family.

Merlita is aware that by using the sanitary toilet, she is reducing health and hazard risks to her family and neighbors as well as promoting environmental protection.
LOAN_USE: to build a sanitary toilet

DESCRIPTION:
Margret, 32, is married with one child. She has two sisters who are dependents that she supports in education and other needs. She operates a small retail shop as her main source of income. She also does tailoring in the same shop to bring in supplementary income.

With her many financial obligations, Margret wants to boost her business in order to increase her income. She has applied for a loan of 800,000 UGX to add stock to her retail shop like groceries and toiletries in order to boost her sales. She believes that she will be able to achieve all that she wishes to achieve, especially giving her family an improved livelihood.

Margret appreciates the support.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Margret, 32, is married with one child. She has two sisters who are dependents that she supports in education and other needs. She operates a small retail shop as her main source of income. She also does tailoring in the same shop to bring in supplementary income.

With her many financial obligations, Margret wants to boost her business in order to increase her income. She has applied for a loan of 800,000 UGX to add stock to her retail shop like groceries and toiletries in order to boost her sales. She believes that she will be able to achieve all that she wishes to achieve, especially giving her family an improved livelihood.

Margret appreciates the support.
LOAN_USE: to stock more groceries in her retail shop in order to increase her income.

DESCRIPTION:
Mrs. Ni Nyoman Notri, wife from the late Mr. Ketut Jingga, started the pig farming business 2 years ago. She started this business with 2 pig huts and 4 piglets. With a monthly average of profit IDR 400,000/ month (approx. US$ 42), this business is the main source of income for Ni Nyoman Notri. Apart from this, sometimes she also receives money from her children who have already married.

Ni Nyoman Notri's daily activities are centered into taking care of the piglets, starting from cleaning the hut to feeding them. Now she already got the additional capital from DINARI which she used to buy 5 additional piglets and pig foods. The pigs are grown quite well and the monthly average profit is now IDR 800,000/ month (approx. US$ 84), enough to provide for daily needs.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Dengan dua lokal kandang yang dimiliki dan 4 ekor bibit babi yang hidup di dalamnya , Ni Nyoman notri istri dari Ketut Jingga (Almarhum) memulai merintis usaha ini sejak 2 tahun yang lalu. Dengan ke untungan rata-rata Rp 400.000 /bulan, usaha ini menjadi sumber pendapatan utama dari Ni Nyoman Notri sejak sepeninggal suaminya , disamping kadang –kadang mendapat kiriman uang dari anaknya yang sudah pada berkeluarga. Keseharian Ni Nyoman notri di sibukan dengan mengurus ternak babi peliharaannya ,memulai dari membersihkan kandang sampai memberi pakan .Kini Ni Nyoman Notri telah mendapatkan tambahan modal dari Dinari yang olehnya di pergunakan untuk tambahan modal ,membeli bibit baru lagi sebanyak 5 Ekor dan sisanya di belikan beberapa sak polard maupun dedak padi untuk pakan ternaknya .pertumbuhan babinya cukup baik dan hasil yang di perolehpun sangat lumayan yaitu Rp .800.000 / bulannya.sehingga cukup untuk memenuhi segala kebutuhan / keperluan sehari-hari .
LOAN_USE: To buy piglets and pig food (Mmbeli bibit babi dan pakan)

DESCRIPTION: Philomene is 38 years old. She sells sodas and beers. She has been in this business for the past 9 years. The loan requested will be used to buy more beers and sodas for sale. The profits will be reinvested in the business.
LOAN_USE: To buy more sodas and beers for sale.

DESCRIPTION:
Melissa is a woman with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Melissa is 37 years old.

Melissa has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell, and other supplies needed in her business.

Melissa has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Melissa would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Melissa is a woman with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Melissa is 37 years old.

Melissa has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell, and other supplies needed in her business.

Melissa has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Melissa would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.
LOAN_USE: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell, and other supplies needed in her business.

DESCRIPTION:
David is a married man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. To earn a living and improve on his standard of living for his family, for seven years, he has been involved in a transport (Boda boda) business. He also farms, growing millet to supplement his income. David is proud of his businesses since he can provide for his family.

He complains of unpredictable climate changes that affect his agriculture business plus the poor road networks in rural areas that break down his motorcycles and cause high maintenance and servicing expenses.

He needs a loan to buy another motorcycle for his transport business.

He plans to put up rental houses in the future to get more income to sustain his family.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
David is a married man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. To earn a living and improve on his standard of living for his family, for seven years, he has been involved in a transport (Boda boda) business. He also farms, growing millet to supplement his income. David is proud of his businesses since he can provide for his family.

He complains of unpredictable climate changes that affect his agriculture business plus the poor road networks in rural areas that break down his motorcycles and cause high maintenance and servicing expenses.

He needs a loan to buy another motorcycle for his transport business.

He plans to put up rental houses in the future to get more income to sustain his family.
LOAN_USE: to buy another motorcycle for his transport business.

DESCRIPTION: Rosa opta por solicitar un nuevo crédito para fortalecer sus negocios de venta antojitos y cultivo de granos básicos. Utilizará el dinero para comprar comprará maíz y hojas de huerta para la producción de tamales, también podrá pagar mano de obra para la recolección de la cosecha. Espera que continuar trabajando para que su negocio crezca.\nCon la inversión anterior logro muy buenos resultados, ya que pudo ejecutar sus actividades agrícolas de temporada en el tiempo justo. Ella comenta que su situación económica ha mejorado gracias al buen uso del crédito.\n
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Rosa chose to request a new loan to strengthen her businesses of selling snacks and cultivating basic grains. She will use the money to buy corn and banana leaves for making tamales, as well as pay for labor to gather her harvest. Rosa hopes to continue working so that her businesses can grow.

She achieved very good results with her previous investment. Rosa was able to conduct her seasonal farming activities in a timely manner. She says that her financial situation improved by using her loan well.
LOAN_USE: to buy corn and banana leaves for making tamales, as well as pay for labor to gather her harvest.

DESCRIPTION:
Good day lenders! Meet one of KSPPS BMI’s clients, Mardiah, who is 38 years old and married. She has two daughters.

Mardiah has had a grocery shop at home for four years. Her husband works very hard, and he has been an entrepreneur in the Tangerang district for seven years. Their income is barely enough for basic needs.

They would like to improve their living conditions and create a happy and healthy life for their kids.

She has asked for a loan of IDR 9,600,000 from KSPPS BMI. This loan will be used to build a clean sanitation facility at their home to improve access to sanitation for their family.

Today her family has no access to a toilet in their home and must rely on the river for bathing. Her family income is insufficient to build a toilet, but Mardiah will be able to repay the loan received.

She and her family want to live a healthy life with clean sanitation. She is very grateful for the opportunity and wants to thank all lenders.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:

DESCRIPTION:
Meet Jackline, a true definition of an “iron woman.” She is obliged to serve her home as well as run her mixed farming business. She does this gallantly.

The living conditions in the Litein area where she lives are not for a faint-hearted woman, but for a diligent woman like Jackline, planning is essential to success. Jackline loves her family more than anything, and this clearly explains why she has never abandoned her responsibilities, even in times of great difficulty. Jackline has entirely depended on farming, not only for the increased profits she gets but also for the opportunity she gets to make her own decisions.

Jackline is seeking an emergency loan to buy farm inputs such as seeds to expand her horticulture farm where she grows vegetables. Loans for small-holder women farmers with little and irregular income are hard to get in her remote village. Only a few organizations, such as Juhudi Kilimo, support farmers like Jackline.

Juhudi Kilimo facilitates loans that empower small-holder farmers like Jackline because the institution believes that women are good and hardworking farmers too.

Jackline is a woman who truly is worth supporting. Support this responsible mum and lend now.

DESCRIPTION: Shirley de 29 años es una microempresaria de Cartagena propietaria de un almacén de variedades en el que además vende helados, jugos y ofrece servicio de fotocopias. Ella vive con su pareja e inició su negocio en el año 2017. Motivada por generar ingresos para su hogar, puesto que había quedado cesante y era el apoyo económico de su cónyuge, identificó la necesidad del sector en el cual no había este tipo de negocio. Ella tiene muchas expectativas de crecimiento y en la actualidad está gestionando su primer credikiva para invertir en mercancías varias: esmaltes, removedores, papelería, lápices de colores, etc. a fin de mejorar el surtido e incentivar las ventas. Apóyale en su préstamo con el que espera mejorar sus ingresos.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Shirley, 29, is a small entrepreneur from Cartagena who owns a miscellaneous items store since 2017 where she also sells ice-creams, juices, and offer photocopy services.

She lives with her spouse and started her business in 2017 after losing her job and observing there was not a similar business in the area. She was motivated to start the business by the need to generate income to help her spouse.

She expects to grow and is currently requesting her first Kiva loan to buy a variety of items such as nail polish, nail polish remover, stationary, crayons, etc. to improve her selection and increase sales.

Support her in this loan that will help her increase her income.
LOAN_USE: to buy a variety of items such as nail polish, nail polish remover, stationary, crayons, etc. to improve her selection and increase sales.

DESCRIPTION: Mrs. Thien T. lives in Bram Bei Mum village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Em Phat, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. In this plantation, they earn not much income to support their family. Thus, Mrs. Thien T. decided to ask for a loan to add her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband, to be motorbike taxi driver. She hopes to increase income and improve her family living with this loan. She is 41 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are construction workers while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the right of photo.
LOAN_USE: To add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to be motorbike taxi driver.

DESCRIPTION:
This is Flocerfida. She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Flocerfida hopes to be able to expand soon, and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship* co-members to share stories of her work every week, when she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.
LOAN_USE: to pay for grocery items and products needed to add to the inventory of her business.

DESCRIPTION:
Greetings from Rwanda! This is SUGIRA CB, a group of entrepreneurs who own different businesses. The group’s name translates to “Be happy” in English.

Perus is 36 years old and is the group’s proud representative. Perus sells fruits at the local market and has been running this business for the past 4 years. Perus has requested this loan to buy more oranges and mangoes to sell at the market to meet customer demand.



Perus hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her standard of living. In the future, Perus plans to see her business grow, and send all her children to school. She thanks you for your support.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:

DESCRIPTION:
Lucila L. is from the village of Kibatang, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 41 and married with three adult children. To make a living, Lucila and her husband own a vulcanizing shop offering vehicle repair services. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Lucila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase materials needed to expand services. This will be the first loan taken out by Lucila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
LOAN_USE: to purchase materials needed to expand services

DESCRIPTION: Hello my name is Dora Zapana and I was born in Cuzco, Peru and lived there until I finished high school. Growing up, I learned a lot from my parents. My mother was a merchant and my father was a missionary, and needed my mother's support because his modest salary was not enough to afford my older brothers' education. Since my mother was a merchant, I always had the idea of doing something similar in my future, while still pursuing my education. When I moved to the capital, I started selling clothing during the week, and preparing and selling food on the weekends.Then in 1995 I moved to the United States with my brother's help. At first I struggled to find work at first since I did not speak English. I worked at a laundromat for a while, but I always cooked for my own family and friends as a way to make a little bit more money every month. After some odd jobs, I eventually decided to focus on doing what I love and started my catering business for special events, and my dream now is to continue to expand the business, and someday open my own restaurant.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED: Hello my name is Dora Zapana and I was born in Cuzco, Peru and lived there until I finished high school. Growing up, I learned a lot from my parents. My mother was a merchant and my father was a missionary, and needed my mother's support because his modest salary was not enough to afford my older brothers' education. Since my mother was a merchant, I always had the idea of doing something similar in my future, while still pursuing my education. When I moved to the capital, I started selling clothing during the week, and preparing and selling food on the weekends.Then in 1995 I moved to the United States with my brother's help. At first I struggled to find work at first since I did not speak English. I worked at a laundromat for a while, but I always cooked for my own family and friends as a way to make a little bit more money every month. After some odd jobs, I eventually decided to focus on doing what I love and started my catering business for special events, and my dream now is to continue to expand the business, and someday open my own restaurant.
LOAN_USE: a seasoned Peruvian cook invest in promoting her cooking business to attract more clients.

DESCRIPTION:
Amina is a married woman with one child, who is too young for school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past five years, Amina has operated a business of making fruit juices from home to sell. She faces the challenge of seasonality in fruits. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers’ needs.

With the KES 25,000 she wants to purchase fruits for making fruit juices to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.
LOAN_USE: to purchase fruits for making fruit juice to sell.

DESCRIPTION:
Martha A. is 49 years old. She is a divorced mother of two daughters. According to her, both are married and live with their spouses. Martha lives with some grandchildren in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Martha is a trader. She deals in onions. Martha procures bags of onions from the Eastern part of the country and sells in the market square. She says she distributes to retailers and treks to nearby markets to sell.

She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure onions in bulk. Martha is hopeful to improve upon her standard of living and give her grandchildren support to further their education.
LOAN_USE: Procure onions.

DESCRIPTION:
Jonathan is 28 years old. He is single; however, he supports his aging parents and younger siblings with school fees through the cereals business which he runs. Beside the cereals business, he also has a small hotel which boosts his income and enables him to meet his needs.

He is seeking a loan to enable him add stock of more maize for selling. He plans to use his profits to pay back his loan and grow his business. His business is doing well and his main challenge is capital to stock his business well to meet its demands. He has also managed to employ other people through the business that he runs. His dream is to educate his siblings till they are done with their studies.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Jonathan is 28 years old. He is single; however, he supports his aging parents and younger siblings with school fees through the cereals business which he runs. Beside the cereals business, he also has a small hotel which boosts his income and enables him to meet his needs.

He is seeking a loan to enable him add stock of more maize for selling. He plans to use his profits to pay back his loan and grow his business. His business is doing well and his main challenge is capital to stock his business well to meet its demands. He has also managed to employ other people through the business that he runs. His dream is to educate his siblings till they are done with their studies.
LOAN_USE: to add stock of sacks of maize for selling.

DESCRIPTION:
Mirasol works hard to support her family. She is married and has a transportation services business in the Philippines.

Mirasol has requested a PHP 21,000 loan through NWTF to purchase spare parts to repair her multicab.

Mirasol has been in this business for three years.

In the future, Mirasol would like to save money to expand her business.
LOAN_USE: to purchase spare parts to repair her multicab.

DESCRIPTION:
Moses is a married man. He has three children. He describes himself as being optimistic.

Moses operates a retail business where he sells sugar, bread, flour, rice, and other items. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge as being inadequate working capital.

Moses will use the KES 100,000 loan to buy more stocks of bread, flour, soap, and other items.

This is Moses' third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were successfully repaid. He will use the anticipated profits to purchase additional stocks.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
Moses is a married man. He has three children. He describes himself as being optimistic.

Moses operates a retail business where he sells sugar, bread, flour, rice, and other items. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge as being inadequate working capital.

Moses will use the KES 100,000 loan to buy more stocks of bread, flour, soap, and other items.

This is Moses' third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were successfully repaid. He will use the anticipated profits to purchase additional stocks.
LOAN_USE: Moses to buy more stocks of bread, flour, soap, and other items.

DESCRIPTION:
Teresa immigrated to Tucson Arizona about a year ago, where she now has a business where she designs artisan rag dolls and other accessories for children; using her vast experience in design and a degree business administration. She’s seeking to offer a better life for her family, which has settled in Tucson after living for decades in the northern border of Mexico.

Her biggest obstacle in the United States was to get a job with regular income; plus the challenge of the lack of opportunities for new entrepreneurs like her, as well as being financially independent in her new country. She used to make rag dolls in her spare time, her first rag dolls were made for her granddaughters Luna and Natalia. In a short time her dolls became a sensation among the little girls of her granddaughters, and then she began taking custom orders for more rag dolls from their parents, so she decided to start her business, out of necessity and passion for crafts, especially after noticing the joy her rag dolls caused on little girls.

She hopes that this opportunity will allow her to thrive in the United States, while allowing her to support her family with her passion for making artisan rag dolls, giving smiles to girls and parents alike. She wants to inspire other entrepreneurs, regardless of age or financial situation to pursue their dreams.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:

She wants to inspire other entrepreneurs, regardless of age or financial situation to pursue their dreams.
LOAN_USE: increase marketing, upgrade sewing machines and purchase additional inventory - including developing my website to boost sales.
TAGS: user_favorite, user_favorite, #Fabrics, user_favorite, #Woman Owned Biz, user_favorite

DESCRIPTION:
Hello special people!

Monica would be characterized by her neighbors and milk customers as an amiable, honest, dedicated, and charismatic woman. Listening to Monica refer to the different breeds of dairy cows on her compound, one could mistake her for an agricultural extension officer, which she is not - she is just a normal farmer.

Monica hails from Eldoret, Kenya, also nicknamed “city of champions.” Monica has much experience in farming. Having practiced farming for the past 12 years, she is considered one of the best dairy farmers in her village. Monica’s primary sources of income are selling milk, eggs, and crops.

Monica is a very dedicated dairy farmer. Monica has space on her farm that is unused, and she wants to use the space to keep more dairy cows. That is why she is kindly seeking a loan to buy another dairy cow and more animal feed.

Through the loan, Monica is going to improve her living conditions and also improve the conditions of her family. She has a ready market for milk, and the area's population is high. Hence, Monica will not have a problem selling the milk and increasing her income level.

Monica does not take the Kiva lenders for granted for taking their precious time amidst their busy schedule to check her short profile and loan request, and hopes that you click that lend button on your computer.
DESCRIPTION_TRANSLATED:
